liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here in Jerusalem, we see missing posters for the hostages everywhere. Just down the road from the ABC's Jerusalem bureau is a handwritten sign strung up outside someone's house. In Hebrew it reads: "First, release the hostages." It's a sentiment shared by many people in Israel. Some families of the hostages say they would have preferred that Israel's government negotiates the release of their loved ones before escalating their ground incursion in Gaza. Among those missing are Tal and Adi Shoham, their son Naveh and daughter Yahel. Tal's dad Gilad Korngold says he trusts the Israeli army to make the right decisions, though three weeks into this crisis, he's struggling to hold onto hope. "There was a lot of hope. Now [there's] less. Every day with no signs from them, it's terrible," he said. A military liaison stays in regular contact with Gilad, but he says they came up with an arrangement that helps him get through the night without lying there waiting for the phone to ring. "He is coming three times a week to my house to talk to us, but we agreed that if something terrible happened, he will not call me up that night."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The families of the hostages say they're struggling to hold onto hope

children.content: Here in Jerusalem, we see missing posters for the hostages everywhere.

props.alt: A picture of a grey haired lady with "bring her home now!" written on it

children.content: A missing poster for hostage Adina Moshe.
(ABC News: Rebecca Armitage)
Just down the road from the ABC's Jerusalem bureau is a handwritten sign strung up outside someone's house. In Hebrew it reads: "First, release the hostages."
It's a sentiment shared by many people in Israel.
Some families of the hostages say they would have preferred that Israel's government negotiates the release of their loved ones before escalating their ground incursion in Gaza.
Among those missing are Tal and Adi Shoham, their son Naveh and daughter Yahel.

props.alt: A family sitting on a shoreline

children.content: The Shoham family are believed to be among the hostages held in Gaza.
(Supplied: Gilad Korngold)
Tal's dad Gilad Korngold says he trusts the Israeli army to make the right decisions, though three weeks into this crisis, he's struggling to hold onto hope.
"There was a lot of hope. Now [there's] less. Every day with no signs from them, it's terrible," he said.
A military liaison stays in regular contact with Gilad, but he says they came up with an arrangement that helps him get through the night without lying there waiting for the phone to ring.
"He is coming three times a week to my house to talk to us, but we agreed that if something terrible happened, he will not call me up that night."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong has told ABC Radio Melbourne innocent civilians should not pay for the horrors perpetrated by Hamas as Israel exercises its right to defend itself. “That is why we have international law and international principles of engagement in conflict. We would continue to publicly assert that Israel should abide by these,” she said. “We have seen a devastating loss of innocent life. There are ongoing civilian deaths … you’ve seen the international response. The reality is the international community won’t accept ongoing civilian deaths. “So when friends like Australia urge Israel to exercise restraint and protect civilian lives it is really critical that Israel listens." Pressed on whether she would condemn Israeli air strikes on Gaza's Jabalia refugee camp, which the United Nations Human Rights Office has expressed could amount to war crimes, Senator Wong reiterated Australia’s position is to urge Israel to protect civilian lives and observe international law. “We want you to exercise restraint because this matters for those innocent civilians who should not be paying for those atrocities of Hamas who does not represent the Palestinian people,” she said. Wong says the Australian government is supporting those families and Australian citizens who got out overnight, and will keep working to ensure they get as many Australians out as possible.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Penny Wong says 'international community won’t accept ongoing civilian deaths'

children.content: Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong.
(ABC News: Adam Kennedy)
Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong has told ABC Radio Melbourne innocent civilians should not pay for the horrors perpetrated by Hamas as Israel exercises its right to defend itself.
“That is why we have international law and international principles of engagement in conflict. We would continue to publicly assert that Israel should abide by these,” she said.

“We have seen a devastating loss of innocent life. There are ongoing civilian deaths … you’ve seen the international response. The reality is the international community won’t accept ongoing civilian deaths.
“So when friends like Australia urge Israel to exercise restraint and protect civilian lives it is really critical that Israel listens."
Pressed on whether she would condemn Israeli air strikes on Gaza's Jabalia refugee camp, which the
United Nations Human Rights Office has expressed could amount to war crimes,
Senator Wong reiterated Australia’s position is to urge Israel to protect civilian lives and observe international law.
“We want you to exercise restraint because this matters for those innocent civilians who should not be paying for those atrocities of Hamas who does not represent the Palestinian people,” she said.
Wong says the Australian government is supporting those families and Australian citizens who got out overnight, and will
keep working to ensure they get as many Australians out as possible.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Orly Halpern in Jerusalem On the morning of the Hamas attack on October 7, Israelis thought that a few dozen militants had broken through the Gaza border fence. The Israeli Defense Force's (IDF) high command had difficulty getting a picture of what was going on because the militants had simultaneously attacked all the military outposts along the border, including the headquarters of the Gaza Division. But within a few days, the estimate rose to 1,500 to 2,000 militants entering through 20 points across the 58-kilometre border fence. Now, after interrogating captured militants, the IDF has a clearer picture of the sheer scale of the attack. It estimates that some 3,000 members of Hamas's military wing infiltrated Israel through dozens of points along the border fence as well as by air (in the form of a paraglider) and sea. This number does not include Gazan civilians who crossed through the torn down fence at about 11am in the second mass wave, some of whom killed people, took hostages and looted. By the time Israel regained control two days later, the security forces had killed 1,000 militants and captured 200. The rest either managed to return to the Gaza Strip or their bodies are still laying around the Israeli border communities. The IDF expects to finish collecting the militants' bodies in the coming days after making sure they aren't booby-trapped.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The sheer scale of the Hamas-led attack on October 7 is starting to emerge

children.content: Reporting by Orly Halpern in Jerusalem
On the morning of the Hamas attack on October 7, Israelis thought that a few dozen militants had broken through the Gaza border fence.

The Israeli Defense Force's (IDF) high command had difficulty getting a picture of what was going on because the militants had simultaneously attacked all the military outposts along the border, including the headquarters of the Gaza Division.
But within a few days, the estimate rose to 1,500 to 2,000 militants entering through 20 points across the 58-kilometre border fence.

props.alt: A man with his fist raised as smoke billows behind him

children.content: Israel's estimate of the number of people who crossed the border on October 7 is continuing to climb.
(AP: Hassan Eslaiah)
Now, after interrogating captured militants, the IDF has a clearer picture of the sheer scale of the attack.
It estimates that some 3,000 members of Hamas's military wing infiltrated Israel through dozens of points along the border fence as well as by air (in the form of a paraglider) and sea.
This number does not include Gazan civilians who crossed through the torn down fence at about 11am in the second mass wave, some of whom killed people, took hostages and looted.
By the time Israel regained control two days later, the security forces had killed 1,000 militants and captured 200.
The rest either managed to return to the Gaza Strip or their bodies are still laying around the Israeli border communities.
The IDF expects to finish collecting the militants' bodies in the coming days after making sure they aren't booby-trapped.

title.children: ASX higher amid increasing market confidence that the US Fed has finished hiking rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There were 4,282 loans issued for the construction or purchase of new homes in September, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Lending in that category over the last three months is 27.7per cent lower than the same quarter last year. The Housing Industry Association's senior economist, Tom Devitt blames the Reserve Bank's interest rate hiking cycle. "Lending activity has been weighed down by the fastest increase in interest rates in a generation. This is drying up the pipeline of new home building work across the country." He warns it means there will be fewer new housing starts next year. "There are very long lags in this cycle due to the record high volume of building work that was in the pipeline when the RBA first raised rates in May 2022. The volume of houses under construction only started declining in the June quarter of 2023, and remains elevated, a year after the first increase in the cash rate. "This large volume of building work has obscured the impact of these rate rises on the broader economy, especially unemployment, as the building industry employs over one million Australians." Mr Devitt ended with this warning: "This slowdown in lending for new housing will make it increasingly difficult to reach the Australian government's target of building 1.2 million new homes in five years."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lending for new homes at 20-year low - effects will be felt next year

"Lending activity has been weighed down by the fastest increase in interest rates in a generation. This is drying up the pipeline of new home building work across the country."
He warns it means there will be fewer new housing starts next year.

"There are very long lags in this cycle due to the record high volume of building work that was in the pipeline when the RBA first raised rates in May 2022. The volume of houses under construction only started declining in the June quarter of 2023, and remains elevated, a year after the first increase in the cash rate.
"This large volume of building work has obscured the impact of these rate rises on the broader economy, especially unemployment, as the building industry employs over one million Australians."
Mr Devitt ended with this warning:
"This slowdown in lending for new housing will make it increasingly difficult to reach the Australian government's target of building 1.2 million new homes in five years."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Coles and Woolworths have been accused of "cashing in during a cost-of-living crisis" by consumer group CHOICE. They've released their annual Shonky Awards and chief executive Alan Kirkland says the supermarket duopoly have been confusing customers, while posting huge profits. "Frequent changes in prices mean it's hard to tell if you're even getting a genuine discount. They are well and truly deserving of a Shonky award." Here's the ABC News article if you want to read more.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Shonky' supermarkets singled out

featuredLink.title: This fridge 'doesn't make things cold'. It's won a Shonky Award, just like Coles and Woolworths

children.content: Coles
and
Woolworths
have been accused of "cashing in during a cost-of-living crisis" by consumer group
CHOICE
They've released their annual
Shonky Awards
and chief executive Alan Kirkland says the supermarket duopoly have been confusing customers, while posting huge profits.
"Frequent changes in prices mean it's hard to tell if you're even getting a genuine discount. They are well and truly deserving of a Shonky award."
Here's the ABC News article if you want to read more.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One last post from me before I sign off and completely hand over to Rach to take you through to the market close. Trade numbers for September are out from the ABS and there's both bad and good news in the numbers. The bad news is that Australia's trade surplus dropped by nearly $3.4 billion to just shy of $6.8 billion. That's the lowest it's been since March 2021. The good news is that Australia is still posting an historically large trade surplus, and also that the reason it shrank is not so much to do with a fall in exports, which were down just 1.4%, but rather a surge in imports (up 7.5%). The good news on imports is twofold. First, it shows demand for goods hasn't completely collapsed — although the 0.3% rise for consumption goods is pretty tiny when you consider how much inflation is pushing up prices, so the volume of consumer goods imports must surely have fallen. The better news is that imports were driven higher by a 23.3% jump in capital goods coming into the country, mainly industrial transport equipment. That is hopefully a sign that businesses are following through with investment plans, and capital goods imports should (in theory at least) be productivity enhancing. But there is another bit of bad news in the data, about what it might mean for Australia's economic growth as measured by GDP and whether we can avoid a technical recession. This from Marcel Thieliant, head of Asia-Pacific at Capital Economics. "The slump in the trade balance in September increases the risk that the Australian economy entered a recession in the third quarter, but we suspect that a large drag from net trade will have been offset by stock building and a modest rise in domestic demand," he writes. "We now estimate that net trade knocked off 1.5%-pts from Q3 GDP growth, which would be one of the largest drags from net exports ever recorded. "But we suspect that will be mostly offset by a reversal of the unusually large 1.1%-pts drag from inventories in the second quarter. "So while today's data increase the risk that the recession we expect to start this quarter already begun last quarter, we suspect that the economy will have continued to expand in Q3." Of course, in per person terms, Australia is already in a recession, with GDP per capita having fallen 0.3% in both of the first two quarters this calendar year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian trade surplus shrinks as businesses up imports, raises recession risks

. That's the lowest it's been since March 2021.

coming into the country, mainly
industrial transport equipment
That is hopefully a sign that businesses are following through with investment plans, and capital goods imports should (in theory at least) be productivity enhancing.

This from
Marcel Thieliant, head of Asia-Pacific at Capital Economics

increases the risk that the Australian economy entered a recession in the third quarter

net trade knocked off 1.5%-pts from Q3 GDP growth

"But we suspect that will be mostly
offset by a reversal of the unusually large 1.1%-pts drag from inventories
in the second quarter.
